bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby and Jefferson Randolph Kean, December 23, 1941

div1.p: Hench has received microfilm of the notebook found at the New York Academy of Medicine and has recognized Lazear's and Reed's handwriting. The contents include case reports of sick soldiers, electrozone experiment notes, observations of non-experimental and experimental yellow fever cases, and notes about mosquitoes. The notebook shows that Lazear was working with mosquitoes even before the Yellow Fever Board was created.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby and Jefferson Randolph Kean, December 23, 1941

opener.salute: My dear General Truby and General Kean:

div1.p:
I had hoped to write you many days ago to send you further data on the
yellow fever note book found by Miss Wood in the New York Academy of Medicine. But
Dr. Malloch, the librarian, didn't pay too much attention to my original letter and
wasn't very prompt even after I wrote him airmail and a telegram. And here it is
Christmas time, so let me first send you both my most sincere and heartfelt greetings
and my earnest wish for your continued health and happiness. I count it a very real
privilege to know you.

I wrote Malloch asking him to lend the notebook to our library as an
inter-library loan, telling him I'd do all I could to study the book in detail and
identify not only the handwritings therein but also try to explain its contents. I
wanted to photostate it here and send you and others full copies for your leisurely
perusal. But Malloch refused to send it and I can't say that I blame him. Then I
asked how much a photostat would cost. He replied, “$24.00”. At the moment that
seems like a lot so I ordered a complete microfilm instead. They finally sent
one about 10 days ago but when I eagerly tried to examine it in our library's viewer
I found every other page had been photographed out of focus! Very sloppy work--one
couldn't even read it. We tried two viewers and our photographic department tried to
blow up the bad pages to see if they would be clear enough to read but they weren't.

More correspondence with Malloch and finally I have a clear microfilm of
the complete notebook. It is very inconvenient to study and I am going to try to make
photoprints from it--these would be cheaper than the price of photostats. Be assured
that when I get a readable copy I will send it to each of you for your study and comments.

While all this correspondence with Malloch was going on I made a copy of
4 pages which Miss Wood had had photostated and which she kindly sent me (I am sending
her a carbon of this letter; I'm sure you won't mind). I recognized Lazear's hand-
writing at once as I have copies of it sent me by Mrs. Lazear. In her letters which
she sent me are certain individual words identical in writing style to those in the
photostats of Miss Wood. Especially distinctive is his way of writing the letter “r”.
But for the sake of complete authenticity I airmailed these four pages to Mrs. Lazear
and asked if she could identify her husband's handwriting absolutely and, if so, would
she certify to that in her own handwriting on each page. She was much interested as
you can imagine and wrote me “There is not the slightest doubt in my mind but that the
writing......is that of my husband.”

Having gotten nowhere with Malloch I sent him (to keep) one of these en-
dorsed pages, thinking he'd appreciate it enough to reconsider and perhaps lend me the
book. But (as I was afraid it might) this made the book all the more valuable and he
still refused.m When I examined the out-of-focus microfilm I recognized Reed's hand-
writing continuing the notes where Lazear's left off but thought that some later pages
were written by still another person. Viewing the clear microfilm I now see that
(with the exception of 2 or 3 inserts) the writing is entirely that of Lazear, then
of Reed and in the back of the book, that of Lazear again. A few pages were written
hastily by Reed and his handwriting looked different but it is undoubtedly that of Reed.

I won't attempt to give you a complete account of the contents but t here
is a brief synopsis:

Pages 7 - 34: Brief handwritten case reports by Lazear concerning various
sick soldiers; about 10 or 12 case reports in all--cases of “diarrhea”, typhoid, chanore,
gonorrheal arthritis, tonsillitis, amebic abscess (necropsy) etc; dates Mar. 2 to May
12, 1900.

Pp. 12-23: Interrupting the above case reports are some notes on
various experiments with electrozone started by Lazear Mar. 14, 1900.

Pp. 37-143 are also in Lazear's handwriting (many single pages not written
on). The notes refer to Lazear's early observations in yellow fever cases, the first
one being that of King May 23, 1900 (see photostat enclosed). Then the cases of Sher-
wood, Hamburger, Jacob Caesar (autopsy), Lutig who had a “restaurant near the railroad
by the yellow fever wards” and who died at Marianao hospital June 17, 1900; notes
on blood cultures and counts from these cases; a note that he caught "eight well filled
brown culices from Colby's mosquito net July 8 and dissected them July 10--“but nothing
abnormal found”. (Lazear was hunting for changes in them analogous to those in malarial
mosquitoes); notes re “mosquitoes sent to Mr. Howard” which were caught at the Barracks,
at Quemados, at Marianao, at Pinar del Rio, at Havana, etc. (Apparently Lazear was
well embarked on his mosquito-yellow fever studies as early as May 23, 1900). There are
notes regarding several patients with yellow fever (spontaneous) at Las Animas Hospital
in August, patients who were bitten by Lazear's mosquitoes, also blood counts on the
patients. Their names are given but unfortunately in this notebook Lazear doesn't have
the names of the unidentified seven early volunteers who were inoculated with Pinto and
Lazear between August 11 and 25. It was a great disappointment to me not to find these
names.

Lazear's last note was written September 13 (was this the last day he was
able to work?) and concerns notes on “guinea pig No. 1 - red” bitten by a mosquito. No
results were noted.

On page 42 there is pasted an insert written in somebody' else's handwriting
as follows:
Folk, A. M. Feb. 3rd. A. O - casts; 1 coarse gr. and few fragments.
Sonntag, Feb. 3. A.M. A. O
West, 7 A.M. Feb. 3. A. O

The dates obviously refer to Feb. 3, 1901, not 1900 and the notes I
suspect refer to urine analyses. Does the A. O simply mean albumen negative?

Pages 105-143 (many pages not written on) are in Reed's handwriting. I
am absolutely sure of this, and briefly describe 14 or 15 of the cases of experimental
yellow fever from the case of Kissinger to that of West (Jan. 31 - Feb. 2). Some of the
errors in spelling of names and dates and hours of inoculation (contradictions I noted
in the Senate Document) can be traced to these notes of Reed, for in several places
he was uncertain of the spelling of Kissenger, Olsen, Hanberry and Handbury, Sonntagg,
Weatherwalk, etc.; also a couple of times he corrected himself writing over some date
and hour of inoculation. On page 129 is the case of Springer bitten by a 16 day
pungens with negative results and on p. 141 notes on the urine of Dr. Ames from Jan. 27
to Feb. 1. (Was Ames sick then?)
Ames Y.F.

Pages 170 to 197 are again in Lazear's handwriting and are his notes on
45 cases of malaria, mostly tertian, dated Feb. 19 to Aug. 17, 1900.

On page 199 are three inserts pasted on the page. One is in Reed's hand-
writing (I believe) as follows:
S O #122 Par. 34 A.G.O. Wash. May 24, 1900
Dr. Reed
Oct. 1-13 Camp Columbia
Oct. 14-20 enroute to U. S.
Feb. 9, 1901 left Havana
Date Agramonte was relieved from the board.

(Below this is written a letter which looks like a double M, like
this MMMm; then “M and P Rolls”.

Obviously these are Reed's notes to himself re the Sternberg order and
Reed's whereabouts on certain dates. Does it infer that Agramonte was discharged
from the board Feb. 9, 1901? What does “M. and P. Rolls” mean?

On page 198 is an insert--somebody's pulse and temperature record Jan.
21-24; and on page 200 a record of the pulse and temperature of Weatherwalks Jan. 31-
Feb. 3. I have not identified the handwriting.

In summary - this is a very historical notebook and I'll bet the Army
Museum would like to know how Malloch got it. Its importance lies in the fact that
it shows how early Lazear began his mosquito work, weeks before the Board got together
in Havana and even before May 24 when Sternberg's order created the board. But it
doesn't give us the answers to many questions that Lazear's other and still-lost
notebook might answer.

Gen. Truby, I was glad to get the photos of the model; they aren't too
good as photographs but are much more accurate in showing the layout of the hospital.
Too bad the one wasn't taken closer! Have you received this week a 31 page article
by Dominguez re “The action of the physicians of the American army in proving the
doctrine of Finlay (comprobacion de las doctrinas). The choice of words is interesting.
He shows a photograph of the banquet (menu card) to Dr. Finlay at Delmonicos Dec. 22,
1900. In Havana there was much debate as to where this banquet was held.

In our library in the clinic I have set up an exhibit, many photographs,
the 2 oil sketches of the Cuban version which Cornwell so kindly sent me, also the
contract which General Kean so graciously gave me. I'll try to photograph the setup
for you. The library had certain labels and notes printed--see the enclosed. Also
to go with it the Proceedings printed the full version of my Cleveland talk (see
enclosed). I'll send you each reprints if you wish more.

By separate post I am sending to Gen. Truby the two maps which at long
last I finally got from Washington.

I have more to write--about a plan of Mr. Peabody to raise money to
memorialize Camp Lazear in honor of two of his college classmates at Dartmouth. An
embarrassing plan because Camp Lazear cannot be dedicated to any outsider no matter
who puts up the money. Nobody can dedicate Camp Lazear; it is already and forever
dedicated, by virtue of its own history, to Finlay, Lazear, Reed, et al. So I'll
have to turn down, diplomatically, some real financial help, I fear. But all for
now or this won't reach you Christmas.
div1.closer:
Every good wish. P. S. Hench, M. D. My kindest regards to
Mrs. Kean. I expect
to stop in Washington
Jan 13-14.
